column3: Pursue enhancement goals and objectives for each brood year outlined in the approved Integrated Fisheries Management Plan Production Plan for the Nanaimo and Chemainus River watersheds. To support stock rebuilding, raise and release up to: ·  225,000 summer run and 425,000 fall run Nanaimo chinook ;  67,500 Chemainus chinook salmon ; 200,000 Nanaimo coho ; To support harvest access, raise and release up to:  900,000 Nanaimo chum ; 1,000,000 pink salmon

column3: To fulfill the purpose of promoting conservation and enchancement in the Nanaimo River area, the NRSS undertakes and supports public education and outreach activities. The activities range from volunteer participation in salmon enhancement activities and educational viewing opportunities, to school programs and salmon fry release opportunities for the public and students. Most stewardship activities align with the timing of salmon enhancement activities across the year.

TCH supports conservation and rebuilding, and harvest enhancement objectives in the Ucluelet area watersheds, Toquaht watershed and enhancement activities in the Clayoquot Sound watersheds that include Tranquil and Upper Kennedy River watersheds. Year round tasks involve implementing best management practices of salmon culture techniques including Salmonid broodstock capture, holding, handling, sorting, spawning, incubation - (inventory, fungus treatments - salt, parasite S, shocking, picking (hand, machine), ponding, marking, flows, experiments, marking (otolith, clips, tags, other), rearing in raceways, channels, tubs, netpens/seapens (diet/growth, pond maintenance, water quality, flow), fish health management, treatment, biosecurity (internal, external), transport, release, adult and juvenile enumeration and sampling. Program preparation, monitoring, troubleshooting, maintenance and clean-up are ongoing tasks. Program strategic planning and broader facilities maintenance occur during periods of reduced biological activity.

column3: Thornton Creek Hatchery works collaboratively with First Nations, volunteer community groups, municipal and federal governments, industry, educational institutions, and other stakeholder groups. The hatchery supports Community Involvement Program Stream to Sea Education programming, including Salmonids in the Classroom. Most stewardship activities align with the timing of salmon enhancement activities throughout the year.
The Organization will work with DFO Stock Assessment to plan and implement an adult chum tagging program in the Lower Harrison River Watershed.
column5: Lower Harrison River Watershed Adult Chum Tagging
column11: 1. Nuxalk Stewardship staff to collect and store data and samples from Bella Coola caught salmon from the FSC fishery in 2020 according to agreed upon instructions. 2. Samplers and monitors to be trained in the importance of their work and they will communicate the importance of annual programs for Atnarko Sockeye recovery to the best of their abilities when interacting with fishers and fish processors. 3. All adipose clipped chinook heads will be frozen as instructions provided. Then inventoried and shipped out for dissection by coordinating with Bella Coola DFO Stock Assessment.
column12: 1. All full, partial and emty scale books will be provided from the 2020 season by the end of August separated by species. 2. A complete database with all datasheets transcribed in Excel for sockeye biological sampling, and river-monitoring sheets by October 5th. 3. Hardcopies of all original datasheets from the biological sampling and catch monitoring in order of date for DFO stock assessement to use for troubleshooting any database issues.

column3: Lower Harrison River Adult Chum Tagging.  Stock assessment program for enumerating chum on the Harrison and Chehalis system using mark-recapture methods.  Dead recovery surveys.   Biologist hired or contracted.
column5: Lower Harrison River Adult Chum Tagging.

column3: The Organization will work with DFO Stock Assessment to plan and implement a streamwalk survey program each Fiscal Year.
column11: 1. Pacific Salmon Treaty (PST) funding will be used to increase data collection of Key Element A/Activity 2-Lower Harrison River Watershed Adult Chum Tagging to improve accuracy and precision of the current statement of work developed in cooperation with DFO FIA Salmon StA. 2. PST funding will be used Annual to improve Work Plan delivery for Fiscal of Years Key2019 Element -2020 A-/_Activity 3-Stream ~Surveys in a manner consistent with the current statement of work developed in cooperation with DFO FIA Salmon StA. 3. All data collected while assisting with the delivery of Activities 2 and 3 above will be included with the data already being collected under the current statement of work and used in the analysis. The data and analysis results will be described in the 2019-20 final technical report.
column12: 1. Data collected while collaborating with the DFO FIA Salmon StA to estimate Fraser Chum Survey Life will be provided to DFO FIA Salmon StA in electronic format (e.g., an e-mailed pdf of the field notes) on a weekly basis with original field notes provided to DFO FIA Salmon StA by December 31, 2019.

column3: Lower Harrison River Adult Chum Tagging.  Stock assessment program for enumerating chum on the Harrison and Chehalis system using mark-recapture methods.  Dead recovery surveys.   Biologist hired or contracted.
column11: 1.The Fishery Manager will work with DFO Stock Assessment to develop and implement a Stock Assessment Plan and Operational Procedures for each fiscal year, and will be reported against in the Year End Reports, through the use of the "Chum Tagging Tasks" checklist developed in 2017. 2.The Organization will hire or contract a Biologist each fiscal year to provide professional service throughout the duration of the project including post project data analysis and production of the final technical report describing the methods and results.
column12: 1.A completed "Chum Tagging Tasks" checklist will be provided in the Year End Reports. 2.A final technical report describing all field and analytic methods, results and copies of all data to be completed and submitted to DFO by July 1 (2018 and 2019).

column3: The Organization will work with DFO LFA Resource Management (Catch Monitoring Biologist) to plan and implement a program to monitor the HFA FSC fisheries.  Monitoring of salmon fisheries within the Fraser River will be coordinated with the Fraser Valley Aboriginal Fisheries Society (FVAFS) or other lead organization.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: 1.The Fishery Manager will work with LFA Resource Management (Catch Monitoring Biologist) to develop and implement a fishing plan and operational procedures for each fiscal year, and will be reported against in the Year End Reports, through the use of the "FSC Monitoring Tasks Checklist" developed in 2017. 2.Fisheries will be monitored by up to 2 staff (hired or contracted) as required by the target species; staff will support field operations and office activities.
column12: 1.A completed 'FSC Monitoring Tasks Checklist' will be provided in the Year End Reports. 2.The Organization will provide details of the number of individuals hired and community affiliation in the Year End Reports. 3.The Organization will provide details of the type of training and number of staff attended in their Year End Reports.

column3: Improve the delivery and accuracy of the chum enumeration program, escapement estimate, and stream surveys for Fiscal Year 2020-2021 by providing additional staffing, equipment, and general operating expenses.
column5: Pacific Salmon Treaty Funds to Support the Lower Harrison River Watershed Adult Chum Tagging and Stream Surveys
column11: 1.The Fishery Manager will work with DFO Stock Assessment to develop and implement a Streamwalk Survey Plan and Operational Procedures for each fiscal year, and will be reported against in the Year End Reports, through the use of the "Stream Survey Tasks" checklist developed in 2017. 2.A Biologist either hired or contracted by the Organization, will provide technical and biological support services throughout the duration of the project including post project data analysis and production of the final technical report.
column12: 1.A completed "Stream Surveys Tasks" checklist will be provided in the Year End Reports. 2.A final technical report describing all field and analytic methods, results and copies of all data to be completed and submitted to DFO by July 1 (2018 and 2019). 3.All stream survey data to be verified and entered into an electronic database and submitted to DFO by March 31 (2019 and 2020).

column3: Purchase necessary materials and fabricate two beach seine nets for use in the Adult Chum Tagging Program.
column5: Surplus Funding - Purchase Two Beach Seine Nets to Assist in the Lower Harrison River Watershed Adult Chum Tagging Program

column3: One Sts’ailes member is hired to work full time at the Weaver Creek hatchery performing set up and dismantle the spawning channel/fish way, dead pitch work, spawner and fry enumeration, site cleanup, and minor repairs.
column5: Operational support technician at the Weaver Creek spawning Channel
column11: 1.The Organization will work with the DFO FIA Salmon StA to develop and implement a Stock Assessment plan and operational procedures incorporating these additional resources for the Fiscal Year 2020-21 to meet the Task Objectives listed above.2.The Organization will hire a biological contractor to provide professional services throughout the duration of the project. For efficiency and effectiveness, it is expected that the Organization will retain the same biological contractor hired under Sts'ailes' Activities Funding Agreement (AFS2018-MLT-1837-2). It is also expected that the coordination of activities between Sts'ailes and DFO FIA Salmon StA to meet the Task Objectives will require meaningful effort on the part of the biological contractor hired by Sts'ailes. 3.All data collected while assisting the delivery of Activities 2 and 3 will be included with the data already being collected in the conduct of Activities 2 and 3 under Sts'ailes' Activities Funding Agreement (AFS2018-MLT-1837-2) and used in the analysis. The data and analysis results will be described in the 2020-21 final technical report that is defined in Sts'ailes' Activities Funding Agreement (AFS2018-MLT-1837-2). 4.All data collected while collaborating with the DFO FIA Salmon StA to estimate Fraser Chum Survey Life will be provided to DFO FIA Salmon StA for inclusion in the final technical report describing all field and analytic methods and results. DFO FIA Salmon StA is responsible for writing and publishing this report. A copy of this report will be provided to Sts'ailes by July 1, 2021.

column3: The organization will purchase a 4x4 ½ ton pickup truck to replace its primary fisheries vehicle which is from 2005, and is worn out from 15 years of heavy use.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - 4x4 Pickup Truck Purchase

column3: Counting fence installation will be carried out by the Organization's technicians and DFO Stock Assessment staff at the Stamp and Sproat Fishway Ladders in early May. 2.The Organization's technicians will be responsible for operating the counting fence and assisting with removing the counting fence at the end of the project.3.Biological sampling operations carried out by the Organization's technicians (as outlined under Monitoring of Spawning Escapements below).Employing at least two Hupacasath community members as fisheries technicians. These employees will work under the direction of Organization staff in order to carry out this activity.The qualified fisheries manager/biologist will assist in building capacity to ensure the successful continuation of the project.
column11: Expected Results: 1. Pacific Salmon Treaty (PST) funding will be used to increase data collection of Key Element A/Activity 2 – Lower Harrison River Watershed Adult Chum Tagging to improve accuracy and precision of the current statement of work developed in cooperation with DFO FIA Salmon StA. 2. PST funding will be used to improve delivery of Key Element A/Activity 3 – Stream Surveys in a manner consistent with the current statement of work developed in cooperation with DFO FIA Salmon StA. 3.All data collected while assisting with the delivery of Activities 2 and 3 above will be included with the data already being collected under the current statement of work and used in the analysis. column3: The Organization works with DFO to conduct adult salmon enumeration and biological sampling at the Stamp, Sproat River and Great Central Lake fish ways from May until November. Work is done under contract with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment Unit (Diana Dobson). The Organization's AFS funded guardian (non-designated) and fisheries manager assist other Hupacasath staff with this work as well as interact with DFO assessment staff regularly throughout the duration of the program. 2.
column11: Spawning escapement areas adjacent to communities are closely monitored. Spawning escapement data is systematically collected, stored and/or disseminated to DFO and others. Field related equipment is acquired, issued and maintained. Individuals are deployed to targeted areas to conduct field work in support of spawning escapement monitoring activities. The Organization's members gain technical expertise. Individuals (at least two) are employed or contracted by the Organization in support of monitoring of spawning escapement.
column12: All datasheets, including Daily Activity Sheets, bypass count sheets and biological data sheets will be faxed to DFO StAD staff or entered into the VidEsc database according to the schedule below for the duration of the contract.  Provide to DFO StAD staff the Daily Activity Sheet by the end of each day the site(s) were visited.Provide to DFO StAD staff updated escapement counts through input into the VidEsc database on a daily basis.Provide to DFO StAD staff the Bypass and the Biological Sample data by the end of the day on which the sampling/monitoring has taken place. This information will be entered into the VidEsc database.   Provide the completed scale books to DFO StAD staff by each Tuesday 10:00 AM until the counting apparatus is removed in approximately mid-November (courier to Carmen McConnell at DFO, South Coast/STAD, 3225 Stephenson Point Road, Nanaimo, B.C. V9T 1K3, unless other arrangements are made for sample pick up).

column11: Spawning escapement areas adjacent to communities are closely monitored. Spawning escapement data is systematically collected, stored and/or disseminated to DFO and others. Field related equipment is acquired, issued and maintained. Individuals are deployed to targeted areas to conduct field work in support of spawning escapement monitoring activities. The Organization's members gain technical expertise. Individuals (at least two) are employed or contracted by the Organization in support of monitoring of spawning escapement.
column12: All datasheets, including Daily Activity Sheets, bypass count sheets and biological data sheets will be faxed to DFO StAD staff or entered into the VidEsc database according to the schedule below for the duration of the contract.  Provide to DFO StAD staff the Daily Activity Sheet by the end of each day the site(s) were visited.Provide to DFO StAD staff updated escapement counts through input into the VidEsc database on a daily basis.Provide to DFO StAD staff the Bypass and the Biological Sample data by the end of the day on which the sampling/monitoring has taken place. This information will be entered into the VidEsc database.   Provide the completed scale books to DFO StAD staff by each Tuesday 10:00 AM until the counting apparatus is removed in approximately mid-November (courier to Carmen McConnell at DFO, South Coast/STAD, 3225 Stephenson Point Road, Nanaimo, B.C. V9T 1K3, unless other arrangements are made for sample pick up).

column3: The Organization works with DFO to conduct adult salmon enumeration and biological sampling at the Stamp, Sproat River and Great Central Lake fish ways from May until November. column11: Hupacasath Fisheries provide adult salmon escapement and biological sampling information to DFO for the Sproat and Great Central Lakes systems from early May to early November. Participate in fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist Diana McHugh. The Organization and DFO (Diana McHugh) agree to Alberni Inlet and Somass River salmon escapement survey schedule and species priorities. Salmon escapement surveys are completed and results recorded on Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) and sent to DFO (Diana McHugh and the DFO Resource Manager) after each survey is completed. Signed Economic Opportunity Agreement for Somass sockeye, chinook, coho and chum (when abundances are sufficient). Signed ESSR Agreement for surplus Robertson Creek hatchery coho and possibly chinook.
column12: Salmon escapement and biological sampling information provided to DFO (Diana Dobson, Carmen McConnell) on agreed upon schedule (usually by the Wednesday morning of each week). Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning meeting recorded in the Meeting Log in the Program Authority Template provided. Results of the planning including the list of streams to be surveyed and species priorities reported in the Year End Report. Completed SILs are sent to DFO (Diana McHugh and the DFO Resource Manager). Reporting obligations for the Somass Economic Fisheries Agreement are met. Reporting obligations for the Robertson Creek ESSR fishery are met.

column3: The objective of the program is to estimate salmon escapement using video counts from the Sproat and Stamp Falls fishways. Counting operations at the Sproat and Stamp Falls fishways will begin in mid-May and run through mid-August, depending on environmental conditions. The Organization will provide trained and experienced observers to review a sub-sample of the video from both sites in order to generate estimates of escapement to each system.  The sub-sampling routine will consist of observers reviewing a portion of the minutes of each hour of video footage. These counts will then be expanded to estimate hourly counts. During times of high fish passage, the observers may only review 5, 10, 15, 20, or 30 minutes of each hour in order to keep up-to-date on counts. During periods of slow migration, the observers may review all 60 minutes of each hour. The Organization will identify fish to species and estimate the portion of marked (e.g., adipose fin clipped) fish. Biological samples of salmon are collected 2-3 times per week from fish at both counting sites to estimate the age and sex composition of escapement.
column5: Spring and Early Summer Salmon Enumeration at Sproat River Fishway and Stamp Falls Fishway
column11: Insight into lake productivity, the surveys will provide valuable information regarding the abundance and condition of the juvenile sockeye in each lake surveyed.Survey results will inform Somass salmon outlooks and forecasts in support of conservation and fisheries planning for First Nations, Recreational and Commercial fisheries.

column3: The objective of the program is to estimate escapement of salmon using video counts from the Sproat and Stamp Falls fishways. Salmon counting operations at the Sproat and Stamp Falls fishways will begin in mid-August and run through mid-November, depending on environmental conditions. The Organization will provide trained and experienced observers to review a sub-sample of the video from both sites in order to generate estimates of escapement to each system. The sub-sampling routine will consist of observers reviewing a portion of the minutes of each hour of video footage. These counts will then be expanded to estimate hourly counts. During times of high fish passage, the observers may only review 5, 10, 15, 20, or 30 minutes of each hour in order to keep up-to-date on counts. During periods of slow migration, the observers may review all 60 minutes of each hour. The Organization will identify fish to species and estimate the portion of marked (e.g., adipose fin clipped) fish. Biological samples of salmon are collected 2-3 times per week from fish at both counting sites to estimate the age and sex composition of Sockeye escapement.

column3: The cost to run the entire program is $22,000.00; the $11,581.00 will be used to install and get all the traps prepared prior to March 31st. The traps will be in operation until June therefore the rest of the work will be conducted in fiscal year 2021-2022. Smolt Out-Migration through Robertson Creek: Estimates of out-migrating sockeye smolts transiting through Robertson Creek will be generated through daily counts of fish captured in the diversion trap. The site will be visited 7 days per week by Hupacasath Fisheries technicians. During each visit all fish will be identified by species and bulk weights will be taken of the sockeye to determine the average weight. During three visits per week 2 technicians will sample the sockeye smolts. Lengths, weights and scale smears (if requested by DFO) will be taken from sockeye smolts. The target sample size will be 100 smolts per sampling event. Maintenance and adjustment of the stop logs and the debris screens will be completed on each visit to ensure flow through the diversion trap is adequate. These activities will be overseen by a Hupacasath Fisheries Biologist and the data will be shared with DFO as requested. Smolt Out-Migration through Sproat River:Sockeye smolt migration through Sproat River will be conducted in conjunction with the Robertson Creek monitoring. A Rotary Screw Trap (RST) will be installed in the Sproat River above the fishway with the use of a contracted helicopter. 3.The installation of the trap will be completed by Hupacasath Fisheries Technicians with assistance from DFO personnel. Once the trap is installed it will be monitored by Hupacasath technicians. The fish will be counted daily and bulk weights will be taken of sockeye. The target will be 100 samples per week for length and weight measurements unless requested by DFO to collect additional samples.
column5: Great Central Lake and Sproat Lake Sockeye Smolt Out-Migration
column11: The Organization will collect adult salmon escapement and biological sampling information from Stamp and Sproat fishways. Salmon escapement and biological sampling data will provide information on salmon age, sex and run composition. This work will inform Alberni Inlet Recreational, Commercial and First Nation fisheries.
column12: Salmon escapement and biological sampling information will be provided to DFO Stock Assessment via the VidEsc database.  Scale samples will be submitted to a DFO personnel.

column3: To hire a company to begin construction of a rotary screw trap (RST). Components to construct are a floating fish rotating screen including a steel trailer; aluminum pontoon base, aluminum fish catch box, and an aluminum cones catching drum. The full estimated cost to build the RST is $51,450.00 plus taxes. The $9,345.00 will be spent this fiscal and the remaining balance will be covered in the 2021-2022 fiscal year. The RST will be used for existing projects to estimate the abundance of the Smolt Out-Migration through Robertson Creek and Sproat River.

1.The Organization, in consultation with DFO, will develop an operational plan for 2019 FSC Salmon catch monitoring. 2.The Fisheries staff will conduct on-grounds routine catch monitoring of Salmon between June and September. 3.Catch Monitoring of FSC Harvest of Salmon by Metlakatla Band members and Non-Tsimshian First Nations under Metlakatla designation in the approach waters to the Skeena River.4.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column5: FSC Salmon Catch Monitoring of all Metlakatla and designated non-members fishing (under Metlakatla designation) in the approach waters to the Skeena River (not including sub-areas 4-12 and 4-15)
column11: 1.The Organization will gain an understanding on stewardship activities in the Goldstream watershed.2.Provide opportunity for staff and/or community members to develop technical understanding in monitoring and stock assessment techniques.
column12: Meeting log of stewardship meetings attended will be provided in Year End Report

column3: Funding to support a portion of the wages for the manager, biologist and fisheries technician in the last quarter of the fiscal year to participate in harvest patrols and make call-outs to the community for FSC numbers and meeting participation.
column5: Metlakatla Aquatic Resources Salaries and Wages
column11: 1.The FC/FT will monitor the FSC fishery, maintain a record of all catch, and provide and disseminate catch information in accordance with the Malahat FSC communal licence.2.The FC/FT will coordinate the Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC)  fisheries as required by the Organization.3.The FC/FT will maintain a list of the persons and vessels designated to harvest on behalf the Organization. This information will be shared with DFO as outlined in the Agreement and communal licence.
column12: 1.The FC/FT will provide in-season catch reports to Jonathan Joe, DFO Resource Manager, as described in the Communal Licence. 2.The FC/FT will provide a document summarizing annual FSC  harvest effort and monitoring activities undertaken.  This report will be included in the Year End Report (Schedule 7).3.The FC/FT will provide to Jonathan Joe, DFO c/o Resource Manager, the list of persons and vessels designated to harvest on behalf of the Organization. Any information will be provided to appropriate Fishery Manager Species Coordinator DFO. (Note: to AFS agreements drafter to take up with AFS Mnager for connection to DFO FAM species manager)

column3: The Organization will purchase an 8600 lb capacity boat trailer for a 24-28' boat, along with insurance.
column5: Surplus Funding - Boat Trailer and Insurance Purchase
column11: 1.FSC Salmon Catch data for areas designated in Metlakatla's asserted traditional territory will be collected and stored in a database, copies of which will be provided to DFO AFS Resource Manager monthly to assist in Fisheries Resource Management decision-making.  Final catch numbers submitted by November 15 (prior to final report).2.The Organization's fishery is coordinated, managed and monitored in accordance with Schedule A of this Agreement.
column12: 1.Catch and Fishery Monitoring records will be provided in electronic form to the DFO AFS Resource Manager by mid-November.2.Summary of the annual FSC Harvests. This report will be included in the Year End Report (Schedule 7).

column3: The Organization will purchase six survival suits for their staff.
The Organization will purchase a replacement rigid hull tender vessel and trailer.
column5: Surplus Funding - Rigid Hull Inflatable Tender Vessel and Trailer Purchase

column3: Drone pilot training for up to 3 staff members; includes travel to Vancouver, 20 hours of ground school instruction with certified drone trainers and Transport Canada online course.
The Organization will purchase a 1 ton work truck
column5: Surplus Funding - Purchase of a Work Truck

column3: The Organization will purchase a containerized mobile wet lab with fume hood and PCR machine. The lab will enable Metlakatla staff to prepare biological samples for biotoxin testing relating to food safety, prepare genetic samples of salmon and other species for stock assessment, conduct marine life experiments with controlled conditions to inform ecosystem management decisions, and clam ageing activities for bivalve stock assessment.
column5: Surplus Funding - Purchase of a Containerized Mobile Wet Lab with Fume Hood and PCR Machine

column3: Funding for MAR dock repairs(15k), and vessel electronics (10k).  The organization will repair, and or upgrade the MAR floating dock office pontoons, decks, electrical inputs, plumbing, baseboard heat and roof.  The organization will replace research vessel electronics including radar, GPS, VHF, battery as well as replacing the dive ladder.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding- Upgrades to the Metlakatla Aquatic Resources (MAR) Dock Office and Vessel Electronics.

column3: In partnership with Lax Kw'alaams, Salmon Catch monitoring of Skeena Estuary approach area (Areas 4-12 and 4-15) for 12 vessel days with two technicians and two training days with Nation biologists. Monitor FSC Sockeye fishing to estimate total effort and catch in the specified subareas.  Determine the extent of Illegal, Unreported, Unregulated (IUU) fishing.  Communication, providing raw data and analysis results will occur pre-, in-, and post-season between Nation biologists and DFO Science staff.
column5: Chatham Sound FSC Creel Survey - Pacific Salmon Treaty

column3: 1.The Organization, in consultation with DFO, will develop an operational plan for 2019 FSC Salmon catch monitoring. 2.The Fisheries staff will conduct on-grounds routine catch monitoring of Salmon between June and September. 3.Catch Monitoring of FSC Harvest of Salmon by Metlakatla Band members and Non-Tsimshian First Nations under Metlakatla designation in the approach waters to the Skeena River.4.

column3: 1.Coldwater River Coho: NWSFA will undertake an adult Coho enumeration project at the Coldwater River fence.  The project will involve enumeration by sex, as well as adipose clip and CWT status through the utilization of a trap box and Sonar technology.  CWT status will be assessed by the removal of marked fish for sampling. Fish released upstream of the trap box will be externally marked to determine if fish have been previously handled. This will assist in the calculation of clip rates from upstream sampling efforts as clip rates will change with the removal of clipped fish at the fence.  Specific technical detail of this project can be found in Supplemental Conditions/Provisions for Fiscal Year 2020-2021. 2.Nicola River and tributaries Coho: As time, budget, and weather conditions allow, other known Coho spawning areas will be checked, and counts of adult Coho performed 3 times over the 3 weeks of expected peak spawn:  Nicola River near Dot ranch; upstream of Nicola and Coldwater confluence to Nicola lake dam and upper Nicola River; plus tributaries such as Guichon Creek, Clapperton Creek, Spahomin Creek, Quilchena Creek and Chutter Ranch side channel. 3.Nicola River Chinook:  NWSFA staff will carry out the carcass recovery and sampling work associated with mark/recapture activities.  Carcass recovery activities will be undertaken in the Nicola River mainstem between the outlet of Nicola Lake and the Dot Trestle, lower Clapperton Creek, Coldwater River downstream of the IR#1 bridge, and Spius Creek downstream of Little Box Canyon. If appropriate (budget- and fish-presence dependant), the upper Nicola River between Nicola Lake and Douglas Lake, and Spahomin Creek, will also be inspected. Other possible Chinook refuge habitat will be surveyed as time, budget and weather conditions allow.
column11: 1.A food and ceremonial (F&C) access plan is developed to meet, in part, Tla-o-qui-aht community F&C needs.2.Catch monitoring, validation, and scheduled reporting of F&C landings and releases are coordinated and reported to DFO WCVI AFS Manager.
column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha'wiih/ Chief and Council approved F&C Fishing Plan and summary of the season's results will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist.  Date and method of submission to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. 2.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Template provided by  NTC as follows:a.Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the fishing season.b.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.c.Groundfish - All groundfish catch to date will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.d.Shellfish - All shellfish will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.e.Herring will be reported by April 8.f.Harvests by a commercial fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.g.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.

column11: 1.Stock assessment enumeration programs will be carried out by NWSFA following the NTA Stock Assessment Chinook and Coho Protocols and Procedures as outlined in Schedule 5 Supplemental Conditions/Provisions (conditions to be finalized in July 2020) for the Fiscal Year 2020-2021.2.Technical capacity of field crew will be maintained and strengthened through on-going interaction/engagement with a qualified NWSFA staff, as well as site visits by DFO biologists and/or experienced technicians. 3.Community members will be employed (2 to 8 individuals). 4.Stock assessment enumeration program data will be provided to appropriate DFO staff in agreed-upon formats and timelines to support informed fisheries management.
column12: 1.Stock assessment enumeration program data and biological samples will be provided to DFO Stock Assessment staff in Kamloops as outlined in the STC Stock Assessment Chinook and Coho Protocols and Procedures as agreed upon and outlined in Schedule 5 Supplemental Conditions/Provisions for the Fiscal Year 2020-2021.2.A post-season summary of stock assessment activities will be provided in the Year End Report.

column3: Under contract with the STC, the Siska Band will carry out in-person interviews with fishers to collect Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) salmon catch information at Siska fishing sites. Crews will also collect biological samples as agreed to with DFO. Catch data is submitted to DFO weekly.  Meetings occur pre-season with DFO for the purpose of training and in-season to share information, resolve issues of concern and facilitate effective coordination of catch monitoring and fishing activities.Specific tasks will include:1.A catch monitoring schedule will be completed by the Siska Band in collaboration with the NWSFA Fisheries Technologist and DFO.  DFO will lead  orientation(s) for monitors prior to start of the program which may include a site visit to fishing areas.2.Monitors will carry out the field data collection according to schedule and will report missed shifts or changes to the schedule to the Fisheries Technologist (or a designated NWSFA alternate staff as agreed to with DFO). The Fisheries Technologist (or alternate) will update DFO as soon as possible to enable schedule modification. Any conservation and protection concerns that monitors have during their shift will be reported to the Fisheries Technologist (or alternate) who will contact the appropriate DFO staff as soon as possible.3.During the program, the NWSFA Fisheries Technologist will verify that the data sheets match the schedule and will coordinate with Siska and/or DFO to address data quality concerns in-season.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management

column3: Top up Key Element A/Activity 2: Stock Assessment Coldwater River Coho and Nicola River and Tributaries Coho. Increase the number of days for rental of security fencing and field office, and contribute to extending the number of days we have staff on site for fence/trap operations (wages). Increased funds will also be utilized to conduct a carcass recovery assessment and allow for necessary travel.
column5: Coldwater River Coho and Nicola River and Tributaries Coho

column3: Top up Key Element A/Activity 2: Stock Assessment Nicola River Chinook. Additional funds will allow for full implementation of the Nicola chinook carcass recovery program.

1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring.  AFS funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.3.Ahousaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring, and biological and enforcement surveys of Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht

column11: 1.FSC Salmon Catch data for areas designated in Metlakatla's asserted traditional territory will be collected and stored in a database, copies of which will be provided to DFO AFS Resource Manager monthly to assist in Fisheries Resource Management decision-making.  Final catch numbers submitted by November 15 (prior to final report).2.The Organization's fishery is coordinated, managed and monitored in accordance with Schedule A of this Agreement.
column12: 1.Catch and Fishery Monitoring records will be provided in electronic form to the DFO AFS Resource Manager by mid-November.2.Summary of the annual FSC Harvests. This report will be included in the Year End Report (Schedule 7).

column3: 1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring. column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys on the Atleo, Bawden Creek, Hootla Kootla, Ice, Upper Megin and Whitepine Rivers. 2.Conduct CFIA bio-toxin sampling weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April. 3.Conduct six or more general monitoring surveys (e.g., sea-lice, clam, sea otters) and six or more enforcement surveys (e.g., recreational fisheries or food fishery) and other surveys (e.g., herring) as contracted by DFO (if applicable).  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities. 4.Monitor the environment in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys on Stream Inspection Log reports will be provided to DFO Stock Assessment, cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April via pre-paid courier. Provide dates and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.3.Summary of survey and monitoring results to relevant DFO staff and DFO WCVI AFS Manager, and listed in the AFS Year End Report.4.Relevant information about the environment and species in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee will be reported to the appropriate DFO staff in-season and summarized in the Year End Report.

column3: 1.Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Ditidaht. a.Enumerate adult Hobiton River sockeye by installing and operating an adult salmon counting fence from April to June. b.Prepare the juvenile trap site and install Rotary Screw Trap (provided by DFO) with assistance from DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Uu-a-thluk staff. c.Two to three Cheewaht salmon spawner surveys will occur from October to November. d.Nitinat Lake assessment fisheries:  using food and ceremonial fisheries and Nitinat hatchery chinook, chum and coho broodstock collections to gather information with DFO on run-timing, distribution and age structure of chinook, coho and chum returning to Nitinat Lake from August to November. AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.

column3: 1.Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Ditidaht. a.Enumerate adult Hobiton River sockeye by installing and operating an adult salmon counting fence from April to June. b.Prepare the juvenile trap site and install Rotary Screw Trap (provided by DFO) with assistance from DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Uu-a-thluk staff. c.Two to three Cheewaht salmon spawner surveys will occur from October to November. d.Nitinat Lake assessment fisheries:  using food and ceremonial fisheries and Nitinat hatchery chinook, chum and coho broodstock collections to gather information with DFO on run-timing, distribution and age structure of chinook, coho and chum returning to Nitinat Lake from August to November. AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys on the Atleo, Bawden Creek, Hootla Kootla, Ice, Upper Megin and Whitepine Rivers. 2.Conduct CFIA bio-toxin sampling weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April. 3.Conduct six or more general monitoring surveys (e.g., sea-lice, clam, sea otters) and six or more enforcement surveys (e.g., recreational fisheries or food fishery) and other surveys (e.g., herring) as contracted by DFO (if applicable).  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities. 4.Monitor the environment in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc.

column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO StAD and Ditidaht Fisheries staff a.Install and operate a counting fence on the Hobiton River from late April to June (river level dependent) to enumerate returning adult sockeye.  b.Assess and prepare new juvenile downstream Rotary Screw Trap site on Hobiton River in April/May 2021. c.Conduct escapement surveys on the Cheewaht River in October and November d.Conduct assessment test fisheries for chinook, chum and coho in Nitinat Lake from August to November 2.Conduct monitoring and assessments for Nitinat Lake crab at least six times throughout the year.3. Continue to develop a monitoring and assessment program for groundfish using long-line surveys techniques in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.5.Monitor the environment in the area and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc. (e.g., bridge and culvert crossing during heavy rain events along the Carmanah Main, sediment traps in the Cheewaht watershed).6.Assist Nitinat hatchery staff with specific activities (e.g., chinook, chum brood-stock collections, provide staff and vessels for feeding net pen chinook, assist Nitinat hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon).7.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum. Ditidaht Fisheries Program staff and the Organization's Southern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with DFO Nitinat Enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager, in August.8.Participate in fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Escapement survey results are provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment in season and to the DFO WCVI AFS Manager in the AFS Year End Report including:a. Hobiton River adult sockeye enumeration results including dates of Hobiton fence operation, daily escapement data and bio-sampling. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. b.Digital results of juvenile tapping on the Hobiton River reported at the end of trapping operations including dates fished, daily counts by species and bio-samples. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.c.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported on Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. d.Reports summarizing Nitinat Lake salmon assessment activities including abundance and biosampling data, submitted to, Nitinat River Enhancement Facility Manager and as defined above. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Reports summarising crab assessment activities including biosampling data, detailed catch and effort submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report.3.Results from the groundfish survey(s) (survey design, sampling procedures, sampling dates, location, survey catch results, species, weight, etc.) will be submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report 4.Biotoxin monitoring samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to. 6.Summary of number of employees assisting Nitinat hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. 7.Signed ESSR Agreement and a report of all catch by species, number sold, etc. will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager as per the agreed upon in-season catch reporting schedule. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.8. Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon and herring spawning surveys according to survey schedule developed with the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (for salmon surveys) as follows: a.Enumerate adult Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hinkuuas (chum salmon) in September to mid-October by conducting weekly bank or snorkel counts to enumerate spawning salmon from the municipal campground at tidewater to and including the canyon tail spawning bed.  Observation data will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment  (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Ehattesaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to monitor herring spawn distribution, and any food and ceremonial herring fisheries in northern DFO Statistical Area 25.2.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Ehattesaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.3.Ehatteshat Fisheries staff conduct a feasibility study on restoring access for salmon above Zeballos River cascade or falls.4.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in the operation of the Zeballos River hatchery and work closely with the DFO Community Advisor, members of the Zeballos Enhancement Society, youth and community members performing various activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, egg incubation, juvenile salmon rearing and releases and may participate in the future in feeding of net penned chum and other species as approved by DFO).5. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in juvenile Chinook salmon micro-trolling sampling activities coordinated through DFO Science (Jessy Bokvist) including all required sampling protocol training.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht

Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to. 6.Summary of number of employees assisting Nitinat hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. 7.Signed ESSR Agreement and a report of all catch by species, number sold, etc. will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager as per the agreed upon in-season catch reporting schedule. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.8. Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon and herring spawning surveys according to survey schedule developed with the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (for salmon surveys) as follows: a.Enumerate adult Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hinkuuas (chum salmon) in September to mid-October by conducting weekly bank or snorkel counts to enumerate spawning salmon from the municipal campground at tidewater to and including the canyon tail spawning bed.  Observation data will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment  (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Ehattesaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to monitor herring spawn distribution, and any food and ceremonial herring fisheries in northern DFO Statistical Area 25.2.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Ehattesaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.3.Ehatteshat Fisheries staff conduct a feasibility study on restoring access for salmon above Zeballos River cascade or falls.4.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in the operation of the Zeballos River hatchery and work closely with the DFO Community Advisor, members of the Zeballos Enhancement Society, youth and community members performing various activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, egg incubation, juvenile salmon rearing and releases and may participate in the future in feeding of net penned chum and other species as approved by DFO).5. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in juvenile Chinook salmon micro-trolling sampling activities coordinated through DFO Science (Jessy Bokvist) including all required sampling protocol training.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht
column11: 1.Conduct salmon escapement surveys on the Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River from September to late fall and monitor herring spawn deposition and fisheries in February and March.2.Issues or concerns related to fishing, fish and fish habitat are reported to the Council, community and relevant agencies.3. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate on a feasibility study to restore access for salmon above the Zeballos River cascade or falls in the canyon affected by Forest Service Road construction if funded by external sources. 4.Participation, including Ehattesaht students and youth, in the operation of the Zeballos River salmon hatchery including (but not limited to) brood-stock collection, fish husbandry and fry release. 5.Staff and youth will participate in all required protocol training and up to ten days of micro-trolling sampling for juvenile Chinook salmon during October-March period.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys according to survey schedules as follows:a.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results including dates of snorkel survey results will be put on Stream Inspection Logs and bio-samples are provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the Third Quarter and AFS Year End Report. 2.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to.3.Summary of the status of the Zeballos River salmon access improvements feasibility, and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including to which agency and contact person the concerns were delivered.4. Summary of number of youth and volunteers assisting with each of the Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hatchery activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. Description of hatchery activities by Ehattesaht Fisheries program staff will also be included in AFS Year End Report.5. Summary of AFS funded Ehattesaht Fisheries staff activities and Ehattesaht youth's participation in micro-trolling activities will be reported in the AFS Year End Report as well as all required reporting/deliverables to DFO Science.

column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails alongside some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.

column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys for coho and chum on Ah'ta'apq, Tsa-ya, Sachie, Ay-yi-sagh, Yaaksis, Maahpe, Purdon, Tsa-Aio and Teamut streams according to a survey schedule developed with the NTC biologist, DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff and Hesquiaht Fisheries.2.Construct or re-establish and maintain one or more trails alongside a stream scheduled to undergo salmon escapements surveys.3. Conduct one or more assessments such as herring spawn, sea otter, crab, geoduck or clam surveys in Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee.4.Conduct one or more stream restoration projects in Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee, dependant on external funding.5.Support from the Hesquiaht Fisheries staff to construct and install as well as operate fish fences on Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake for the collection of salmon escapement data.  Data provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and DFO AFS Manager at the end of the project.
column12: 1.Results of salmon escapement surveys using Stream Inspection Logs provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Summary of results maintaining trail access in support of salmon escapement surveys will be included in the AFS Year End Report (at least two photos will be included). 3.Summary of survey and monitoring (i.e. fish fence counts) results provided to relevant DFO staff (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) and dates and results of survey listed in AFS Year End Report. 4.AFS Year End Report will include a brief update on stream restoration projects.5.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Uu-a-thluk Regional Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. a.Enumerate Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye and Chinook at Burman River, visual surveys (2-3 surveys) from September to November. b.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff will implement a bus route CREEL monitoring program for Gold River sockeye fisheries to estimate catch and effort by seine, dipnet and hook and line.2.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. 3. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Mowachaht/Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.4. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) and Conuma hatchery staff (e.g., salmon collections, juvenile salmon releases and feeding net pen chinook and chum).5.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff work with DFO and the Organization's staff on the planning and development of an Excess Salmon to Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Conuma River chinook, coho and chum if abundances are deemed sufficient.6.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works with DFO to coordinate for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning and information flow.

column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Mowachaht/Muchalaht
column11: 1.Salmon escapement survey work by the Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff includes:a.Conducting escapement surveys for sockeye salmon on the Oktwanch River (Gold) from September to early November.b.Conducting a bus route survey for Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye fisheries c. Supporting contracted escapement projects with DFO StAD tentatively identified at Tsowwin, Canton, and Oktwanch and Burman Rivers. d.Supporting Conuma Chinook mark-recapture2.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.3.Monitor the environment in the Mowachaht/ Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such Environment & Climate Change Canada, DFO, Province of BC Forest, Lands and Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, etc. (e.g., derelict float homes, logging erosion, rate of cut considerations affecting salmon production).4. Assist Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) with activities in relation to production Chinook from the Gold and Burman Rivers satellite programs with Conuma hatchery (e.g., Chinook, chum and brood-stock collections, biosampling provide NSWS assistance for feeding net pen Chinook, assist Conuma hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon) and participate in the annual production planning for Conuma hatchery with DFO SEP staff 5.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Conuma Chinook, Coho and Chum. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries program staff and the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with Conuma DFO enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager in August.6.Participate in juvenile fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys according to survey schedules as follows:a.Oktwanch and Burman rivers Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment Biologist (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Reports summarizing CREEL results including effort, catch and gear type, provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.3.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to.4.Summary of number of employees assisting Conuma hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of Mowachaht/Muchalaht priorities and  recommendations regarding Conuma hatchery production planning and other salmon enhancement efforts for Area 25 will be provided to DFO SEP through production planning process.6.Signed ESSR Agreement (if viable ESSR opportunity develops) and completion of all catch reporting requirements  provided to DFO Resource Manager (Amy Greenwood) weekly. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.7.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Uu-a-thluk Regional Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. a.Enumerate Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye and Chinook at Burman River, visual surveys (2-3 surveys) from September to November. b.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff will implement a bus route CREEL monitoring program for Gold River sockeye fisheries to estimate catch and effort by seine, dipnet and hook and line.2.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. 3. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Mowachaht/Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.4. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) and Conuma hatchery staff (e.g., salmon collections, juvenile salmon releases and feeding net pen chinook and chum).5.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff work with DFO and the Organization's staff on the planning and development of an Excess Salmon to Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Conuma River chinook, coho and chum if abundances are deemed sufficient.6.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works with DFO to coordinate for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning and information flow.

Supporting contracted escapement projects with DFO StAD tentatively identified at Tsowwin, Canton, and Oktwanch and Burman Rivers. d.Supporting Conuma Chinook mark-recapture2.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.3.Monitor the environment in the Mowachaht/ Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such Environment & Climate Change Canada, DFO, Province of BC Forest, Lands and Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, etc. (e.g., derelict float homes, logging erosion, rate of cut considerations affecting salmon production).4. column3: 1.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor, sound, and survey herring spawning waters.2.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor and survey spawning streams for salmon.  Reporting live count and carcasses on 2 streams: Espinosa, Savey Creek (Owossista, and Mary Basin, if conditions permit). 3.Nuchatlaht staff will monitor spawning waters for both herring and salmon for activities that may impact spawning areas, such as upland activity disturbances that may affect water, sediment and large wood debris, cover in the "shore zone," and/or sedimentation of salmon spawning habitat.4.Nuchatlaht staff will plan protections for estuaries and watersheds from industrial activities in the form of Salmon Forest Conservation Areas in the Owiissta/Apple Creeks and the Shoomaht/Ransom Creek (Nuu-chah-nulth Salmon Forest Ecological Network watersheds).
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Nuchatlaht

column3: 1.Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff support the Salmon Enhancement Program to rehabilitate salmon stocks and key habitat in the Kennedy watershed.2.Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff monitor and conduct escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff, the Organization's Central Region Fisheries biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment.3.Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries conduct general monitoring and surveying of Tla-o-qui-aht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Tla-o-qui-aht
column11: 1.Conduct broodstock capture in the Upper Kennedy River. Training of hatchery staff, dealing with the fertilization, incubation and rearing of chinook eggs and fry.2.Plan to expand Tla-o-qui-aht's hatchery operations by investigating the feasibility of other enhancement sites and enhancement of other species (i.e. Sockeye). This will be done in conjunction with Kennedy Watershed Sockeye restoration planning.3.Conduct and/or assist with escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO and Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff on Kennedy River systems (i.e. Muriel Lake, Staghorn Creek, Angora Creek and Lower Kennedy and Kennedy Lake).4.Conduct three or more general monitoring surveys (e.g. sea otters) and other surveys as contracted by DFO (if applicable). Monitor the environment in Tla-o-qui-aht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment and DFO.  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities.
column12: 1.Summary of broodstock capture dates and activities supporting SEP activities in the Kennedy watershed will be included in the AFS Year End Report2. The progress on Tla-o-qui-aht's hatchery operations will be summarized in AFS Year End Report. 3.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) and DFO Community Advisor on SILs, in-season, according to survey schedule developed with DFO and Tla-o-qui-aht via pre-paid priority post envelopes provided by DFO. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.4.Summary of results will be included in the AFS Year End Report. 5.Summary of survey and monitoring results to relevant DFO staff (cc WCVI AFS Manager), and dates and results of survey listed in AFS Year End Report. (e.g., sea otter survey information will be reported to DFO Science Branch, in-season and summarized in the AFS Year End Report).

column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column5: Food and Ceremonial Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht
column11: 1.A food and ceremonial (F&C) access plan is developed to meet, in part, Ahousaht community F&C needs.2.Catch monitoring, validation, and scheduled reporting of F&C landings and releases are coordinated and reported to DFO WCVI AFS Manager.
column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha’wiih/ Chief and Council approved F&C fishing plan and summary of the season’s results will be provided to DFO (WCVI AFS Manager) and the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist.  Date and method of submission to DFO will be provided in the AFS Year End Report. 2.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Template provided by NTC as follows:a.Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the fishing season.b.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022. f.Harvests by a commercial fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.g.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.

column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff work annually on food and ceremonial Fishing Plan(s) which are provided to DFO through the Uu-a-thluk/ DFO Joint Technical Working Group meetings.2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff provides catch monitoring information to DFO throughout the year.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column5: Food and Ceremonial Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column11: 1.A food and ceremonial (F&C) access plan is developed to meet, in part, Ditidaht community F&C needs.2.Catch monitoring, validation, and scheduled reporting of F&C landings and releases are coordinated and reported to DFO WCVI AFS Manager.
column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha'wiih (hereditary Chiefs)/ Chief and Council approved F&C Fishing Plan and summary of the season's results will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Southern Region Fisheries Biologist.  Provide date and method of submission to DFO in AFS Year End Report. 2.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Southern Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Template provided by NTC as follows:a.Barkley and Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the fishery.b.Nitinat Chinook - Weekly on the Tuesday of each week, during the fishery.c.Nitinat Coho and Chum - On the last day of each month, during the fishery.d.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.e.Groundfish - All groundfish catch to date will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2021.Shellfish - All shellfish will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.g.Herring will be reported by April 8.h.Harvests by a commercial fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.i.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.

column3: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff annually works on food and ceremonial Fishing Plan(s) which are provided to DFO through the Uu-a-thluk/ DFO Joint Technical Working Group meetings.2. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries Department will hire two community members for catch monitoring of Gold River Sockeye salmon F&C fisheries.3.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff provides catch monitoring information to DFO throughout the year.4.Two or more fisheries related community events are organized (e.g., Fisheries Planning, guidelines and conditions of License information sessions, fisher meetings for development of Fishing Plan).
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
