column3: 1.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff annually works on food and ceremonial Fishing Plan(s) for which are provided to DFO through the Uu-a-thluk/ DFO Joint Technical Working Group meetings.2.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff provides catch monitoring information to DFO throughout the year according to the schedule outlined below.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column5: Food and Ceremonial Fisheries Management- Nuchatlaht
column11: 1.A food and ceremonial (F&C) access plan is developed to meet, in part, Hesquiaht community food and ceremonial F&C needs.2.Catch monitoring, validation, and scheduled reporting of F&C landings and releases are coordinated and reported to DFO (WCVI AFS Manager).
column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha'wiih/ Chief and Council approved F&C Fishing Plan and summary of the season's results will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist.  Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.2.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Template provided by NTC as follows:a.Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the Fishing season.b.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.c.Groundfish - All groundfish catch to date will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.d.Shellfish - All shellfish will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.e.Herring will be reported by April 8.f.Harvests by a commercial Fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.g.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.

column3: 1.Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff annually works on food and ceremonial Fishing plan(s) which are provided to DFO through the Uu-a-thluk/ DFO Joint Technical Working Group meetings. 2.Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff provides on the water and at the dock F&C catch monitoring information to DFO throughout the year.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column5: Food and Ceremonial Fisheries Management- Tlaoquiaht
column11: 1.A food and ceremonial (F&C) access plan is developed to meet, in part, Mowachaht/Muchalaht community F&C needs.2.Fisheries Coordinator and Technician will interview and interact with community members to collect harvest information on F&C fisheries.3.Catch monitoring, validation, and scheduled reporting of F&C landings and releases are coordinated and reported to DFO WCVI AFS Manager.4.Community events are organized and supported by Mowachaht/Muchalaht fisheries staff (e.g., fisher meetings to discuss F&C Fishing plans).
column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha'wiih/ Chief and Council approved F&C Fishing Plan and summary of the season's results will be provided to DFO (WCVI AFS Manager) and the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist.  Date and method of submission to DFO will be provided in the AFS Year End Report. 2.Mowachaht/Muchalaht catch monitors will report each day's data, catch and effort information to the Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries Manager. Harvest catch numbers will be compiled into a report for DFO according to the schedule below.3.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO AFSManager and the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Form Template provided by NTC as follows:a.Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the fishing season.b.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.c.Groundfish - All groundfish catch to date will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.d.Shellfish - All shellfish will be reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022.e.Herring will be reported by April 8.f. Harvests by a commercial fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.g.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.h.Type of community event, purpose, date, and who attended will be reported using the Community Events Log in the Program Authority Template provided by NTC.

column3: 1.Ditidaht will ensure required maintenance for their 2015 Ford F-350 is complete2.Ditidaht will ensure fisheries fieldwork gear is repaired (seine net) or replaced (groundfish gear)3.Ditidaht will purchase a gill net4.Ditidaht will enroll in Office Administration training for Fisheries Managers as well as MED and SRT1 (Marine basic first aid and Swiftwater) training courses for Fisheries technicians.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Patrol Boat equipment replacement/maintenance and training (capital acquisition and capacity support)-Ditidaht

column3: Following receipt of engineered design (in-kind contribution), Ehattesaht will oversee the Zeballos Community hatchery project to re-establish water supply, upgrade plumbing system including installation of circular tanks as well as improve biosecurity
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Repair and upgrade community hatchery (capital infrustructure and capacity support)-Ehattesaht

column3: 1.Hesquiaht will replace two computers in their fisheries office with appropriate laptops and software to support fisheries program office work, including allowing for remote video conferencing participation in meetings.2.Hesquiaht will purchase two 150 HP outboards to replace existing 300 HP single outboard 3.Hesquiaht will purchase an ATV for Fisheries Technician use
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Acquisition of office equipment, outboard motors and ATV (capital acquisition)-Hesquiaht

column3: Nuchatlaht will purchase a Steel warehouse building including overseeing the planning, development and construction phases.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Steel Shelter Boat and Trailer Storage (Capital Infustructure)- Nuchatlaht

column3: Tla-o-qui-aht will purchase a new fisheries patrol vessel as a replacement to the inflatable rigid hull boat
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Replacement of Fisheries Patrol Vessel (capital acquisition)-Tla-o-qui-aht

column3: Ahousaht will purchase a stove, sink, heater and a new life raft for their fisheries patrol vessel.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding - Patrol Boat equipment and life raft (capital acquisition)- Ahousaht

column3: 1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring.  AFS funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.3.Ahousaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring, and biological and enforcement surveys of Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys on the Atleo, Bawden Creek, Hootla Kootla, Ice, Upper Megin and Whitepine Rivers. 2.Conduct CFIA bio-toxin sampling weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April. 3.Conduct six or more general monitoring surveys (e.g., sea-lice, clam, sea otters) and six or more enforcement surveys (e.g., recreational fisheries or food fishery) and other surveys (e.g., herring) as contracted by DFO (if applicable).  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities. 4.Monitor the environment in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys on Stream Inspection Log reports will be provided to DFO Stock Assessment, cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April via pre-paid courier. Provide dates and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.3.Summary of survey and monitoring results to relevant DFO staff and DFO WCVI AFS Manager, and listed in the AFS Year End Report.4.Relevant information about the environment and species in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee will be reported to the appropriate DFO staff in-season and summarized in the Year End Report.

column3: 1.Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to a survey schedule developed with Ahousaht Fisheries, the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist, the Ahousaht/ Fish Farm Enhancement Committee, and with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. 2.With the assistance of external funding from Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ahousaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring.  AFS funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ahousaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.3.Ahousaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring, and biological and enforcement surveys of Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ahousaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys on the Atleo, Bawden Creek, Hootla Kootla, Ice, Upper Megin and Whitepine Rivers. 2.Conduct CFIA bio-toxin sampling weekly from May to October and bi-weekly from November to April. 3.Conduct six or more general monitoring surveys (e.g., sea-lice, clam, sea otters) and six or more enforcement surveys (e.g., recreational fisheries or food fishery) and other surveys (e.g., herring) as contracted by DFO (if applicable).  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities. 4.Monitor the environment in Ahousaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc.

column3: 1.Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Ditidaht. a.Enumerate adult Hobiton River sockeye by installing and operating an adult salmon counting fence from April to June. b.Prepare the juvenile trap site and install Rotary Screw Trap (provided by DFO) with assistance from DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and Uu-a-thluk staff. c.Two to three Cheewaht salmon spawner surveys will occur from October to November. d.Nitinat Lake assessment fisheries:  using food and ceremonial fisheries and Nitinat hatchery chinook, chum and coho broodstock collections to gather information with DFO on run-timing, distribution and age structure of chinook, coho and chum returning to Nitinat Lake from August to November. AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.

column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO StAD and Ditidaht Fisheries staff a.Install and operate a counting fence on the Hobiton River from late April to June (river level dependent) to enumerate returning adult sockeye.  b.Assess and prepare new juvenile downstream Rotary Screw Trap site on Hobiton River in April/May 2021. c.Conduct escapement surveys on the Cheewaht River in October and November d.Conduct assessment test fisheries for chinook, chum and coho in Nitinat Lake from August to November 2.Conduct monitoring and assessments for Nitinat Lake crab at least six times throughout the year.3. Continue to develop a monitoring and assessment program for groundfish using long-line surveys techniques in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.5.Monitor the environment in the area and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc. (e.g., bridge and culvert crossing during heavy rain events along the Carmanah Main, sediment traps in the Cheewaht watershed).6.Assist Nitinat hatchery staff with specific activities (e.g., chinook, chum brood-stock collections, provide staff and vessels for feeding net pen chinook, assist Nitinat hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon).7.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum. Ditidaht Fisheries Program staff and the Organization's Southern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with DFO Nitinat Enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager, in August.8.Participate in fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Escapement survey results are provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment in season and to the DFO WCVI AFS Manager in the AFS Year End Report including:a. Hobiton River adult sockeye enumeration results including dates of Hobiton fence operation, daily escapement data and bio-sampling. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. b.Digital results of juvenile tapping on the Hobiton River reported at the end of trapping operations including dates fished, daily counts by species and bio-samples. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.c.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported on Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. d.Reports summarizing Nitinat Lake salmon assessment activities including abundance and biosampling data, submitted to, Nitinat River Enhancement Facility Manager and as defined above. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Reports summarising crab assessment activities including biosampling data, detailed catch and effort submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report.3.Results from the groundfish survey(s) (survey design, sampling procedures, sampling dates, location, survey catch results, species, weight, etc.) will be submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report 4.Biotoxin monitoring samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to. 6.Summary of number of employees assisting Nitinat hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. 7.Signed ESSR Agreement and a report of all catch by species, number sold, etc. will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager as per the agreed upon in-season catch reporting schedule. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.8. Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

AFS covers the wages of the Fisheries Manager and some boat and other equipment expenses.  Ditidaht uses internal funding to cover all other costs. 2.Nitinat Lake crab are monitored and assessed at least six times throughout the year.3.Ditidaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to develop and implement groundfish monitoring and assessment in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Ditidaht Fisheries staff conducts bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. AFS funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses to assist with the monitoring.  CFIA funding pays for Ditidaht Fisheries boat operating expenses and shipping of samples.5.Ditidaht Fisheries conduct general monitoring of Ditidaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.6.Ditidaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nitinat hatchery staff with activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, towing net-pens, feeding net penned fish, etc). 7.Ditidaht Fisheries work with DFO and the Organization's staff to develop an Escapement Salmon Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum, where abundances are appropriate.8.Ditidaht Fisheries staff work with DFO for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning.
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO StAD and Ditidaht Fisheries staff a.Install and operate a counting fence on the Hobiton River from late April to June (river level dependent) to enumerate returning adult sockeye.  b.Assess and prepare new juvenile downstream Rotary Screw Trap site on Hobiton River in April/May 2021. c.Conduct escapement surveys on the Cheewaht River in October and November d.Conduct assessment test fisheries for chinook, chum and coho in Nitinat Lake from August to November 2.Conduct monitoring and assessments for Nitinat Lake crab at least six times throughout the year.3. Continue to develop a monitoring and assessment program for groundfish using long-line surveys techniques in DFO Statistical Areas 21/121.4.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.5.Monitor the environment in the area and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment, DFO, etc. (e.g., bridge and culvert crossing during heavy rain events along the Carmanah Main, sediment traps in the Cheewaht watershed).6.Assist Nitinat hatchery staff with specific activities (e.g., chinook, chum brood-stock collections, provide staff and vessels for feeding net pen chinook, assist Nitinat hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon).7.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Nitinat Lake chinook, coho and chum. Ditidaht Fisheries Program staff and the Organization's Southern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with DFO Nitinat Enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager, in August.8.Participate in fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Escapement survey results are provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment in season and to the DFO WCVI AFS Manager in the AFS Year End Report including:a. Hobiton River adult sockeye enumeration results including dates of Hobiton fence operation, daily escapement data and bio-sampling. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. b.Digital results of juvenile tapping on the Hobiton River reported at the end of trapping operations including dates fished, daily counts by species and bio-samples. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.c.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported on Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report. d.Reports summarizing Nitinat Lake salmon assessment activities including abundance and biosampling data, submitted to, Nitinat River Enhancement Facility Manager and as defined above. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Reports summarising crab assessment activities including biosampling data, detailed catch and effort submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report.3.Results from the groundfish survey(s) (survey design, sampling procedures, sampling dates, location, survey catch results, species, weight, etc.) will be submitted electronically (Word, Excel files as appropriate) in the AFS Year End Report 4.Biotoxin monitoring samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to. 6.Summary of number of employees assisting Nitinat hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. 7.Signed ESSR Agreement and a report of all catch by species, number sold, etc. will be provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager as per the agreed upon in-season catch reporting schedule. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.8. Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon and herring spawning surveys according to survey schedule developed with the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (for salmon surveys) as follows: a.Enumerate adult Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hinkuuas (chum salmon) in September to mid-October by conducting weekly bank or snorkel counts to enumerate spawning salmon from the municipal campground at tidewater to and including the canyon tail spawning bed.  Observation data will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment  (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Ehattesaht staff will work with the Organization's staff to monitor herring spawn distribution, and any food and ceremonial herring fisheries in northern DFO Statistical Area 25.2.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Ehattesaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.3.Ehatteshat Fisheries staff conduct a feasibility study on restoring access for salmon above Zeballos River cascade or falls.4.Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in the operation of the Zeballos River hatchery and work closely with the DFO Community Advisor, members of the Zeballos Enhancement Society, youth and community members performing various activities (e.g., salmon broodstock collections, egg incubation, juvenile salmon rearing and releases and may participate in the future in feeding of net penned chum and other species as approved by DFO).5. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate in juvenile Chinook salmon micro-trolling sampling activities coordinated through DFO Science (Jessy Bokvist) including all required sampling protocol training.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht

column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Ehattesaht
column11: 1.Conduct salmon escapement surveys on the Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River from September to late fall and monitor herring spawn deposition and fisheries in February and March.2.Issues or concerns related to fishing, fish and fish habitat are reported to the Council, community and relevant agencies.3. Ehattesaht Fisheries staff participate on a feasibility study to restore access for salmon above the Zeballos River cascade or falls in the canyon affected by Forest Service Road construction if funded by external sources. 4.Participation, including Ehattesaht students and youth, in the operation of the Zeballos River salmon hatchery including (but not limited to) brood-stock collection, fish husbandry and fry release. 5.Staff and youth will participate in all required protocol training and up to ten days of micro-trolling sampling for juvenile Chinook salmon during October-March period.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys according to survey schedules as follows:a.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results including dates of snorkel survey results will be put on Stream Inspection Logs and bio-samples are provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the Third Quarter and AFS Year End Report. 2.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to.3.Summary of the status of the Zeballos River salmon access improvements feasibility, and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including to which agency and contact person the concerns were delivered.4. Summary of number of youth and volunteers assisting with each of the Tahtahtis (Zeballos) River hatchery activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report. Description of hatchery activities by Ehattesaht Fisheries program staff will also be included in AFS Year End Report.5. Summary of AFS funded Ehattesaht Fisheries staff activities and Ehattesaht youth's participation in micro-trolling activities will be reported in the AFS Year End Report as well as all required reporting/deliverables to DFO Science.

column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails alongside some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.

column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails alongside some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding. column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys for coho and chum on Ah'ta'apq, Tsa-ya, Sachie, Ay-yi-sagh, Yaaksis, Maahpe, Purdon, Tsa-Aio and Teamut streams according to a survey schedule developed with the NTC biologist, DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff and Hesquiaht Fisheries.2.Construct or re-establish and maintain one or more trails alongside a stream scheduled to undergo salmon escapements surveys.3. Conduct one or more assessments such as herring spawn, sea otter, crab, geoduck or clam surveys in Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee.4.Conduct one or more stream restoration projects in Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee, dependant on external funding.5.Support from the Hesquiaht Fisheries staff to construct and install as well as operate fish fences on Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake for the collection of salmon escapement data.  Data provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and DFO AFS Manager at the end of the project.
column12: 1.Results of salmon escapement surveys using Stream Inspection Logs provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Summary of results maintaining trail access in support of salmon escapement surveys will be included in the AFS Year End Report (at least two photos will be included). 3.Summary of survey and monitoring (i.e. fish fence counts) results provided to relevant DFO staff (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) and dates and results of survey listed in AFS Year End Report. 4.AFS Year End Report will include a brief update on stream restoration projects.5.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column12: 1.Results of salmon escapement surveys using Stream Inspection Logs provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails alongside some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Hesquiaht
column11: 1.Conduct escapement surveys for coho and chum on Ah'ta'apq, Tsa-ya, Sachie, Ay-yi-sagh, Yaaksis, Maahpe, Purdon, Tsa-Aio and Teamut streams according to a survey schedule developed with the NTC biologist, DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff and Hesquiaht Fisheries.2.Construct or re-establish and maintain one or more trails alongside a stream scheduled to undergo salmon escapements surveys.3. Data provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and DFO AFS Manager at the end of the project.
column12: 1.Results of salmon escapement surveys using Stream Inspection Logs provided to DFO Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Summary of results maintaining trail access in support of salmon escapement surveys will be included in the AFS Year End Report (at least two photos will be included). 3.Summary of survey and monitoring (i.e. fish fence counts) results provided to relevant DFO staff (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) and dates and results of survey listed in AFS Year End Report. 4.AFS Year End Report will include a brief update on stream restoration projects.5.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff conduct salmon escapement surveys. 2.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will construct new or re-establish old trails alongside some of the streams that will undergo salmon escapement surveys.   3.Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will conduct general monitoring and biological surveys of Hesquiaht Ha-houlthee. 4.Hesquiaht Fisheries will continue to work with Central Westcoast Forest Society (CWFS) on stream restoration work for Ay-yi-sagh Creek, the extent of work completed will be dependent on external funding.  AFS funding pays for Hesquiaht Fisheries staff wages and related expenses, if funding is not available through CWFS.  CWFS pays for any other expenditures required for the project.  Hesquiaht Fisheries only participates in the work if funding is available by CWFS.5. Hesquiaht Fisheries staff will support the construction and installation of a counting fence at Purdon Creek and Hisnit Lake to enumerate adult salmon escapement.

Data provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment and DFO AFS Manager at the end of the project.

column3: 1.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conducts escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with Uu-a-thluk Regional Biologist and DFO South Coast Stock Assessment staff. a.Enumerate Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye and Chinook at Burman River, visual surveys (2-3 surveys) from September to November. b.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff will implement a bus route CREEL monitoring program for Gold River sockeye fisheries to estimate catch and effort by seine, dipnet and hook and line.2.With the assistance of external funding from the Canada Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct bio-toxin monitoring from May to October. 3. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff conduct general monitoring of Mowachaht/Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report issues or concerns to the community and relevant agencies.4. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works closely with the Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) and Conuma hatchery staff (e.g., salmon collections, juvenile salmon releases and feeding net pen chinook and chum).5.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff work with DFO and the Organization's staff on the planning and development of an Excess Salmon to Spawning Requirements (ESSR) agreement for Conuma River chinook, coho and chum if abundances are deemed sufficient.6.Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff works with DFO to coordinate for fall salmon stock assessment survey planning and information flow.

column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Mowachaht/Muchalaht
column11: 1.Salmon escapement survey work by the Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff includes:a.Conducting escapement surveys for sockeye salmon on the Oktwanch River (Gold) from September to early November.b.Conducting a bus route survey for Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye fisheries c. Supporting contracted escapement projects with DFO StAD tentatively identified at Tsowwin, Canton, and Oktwanch and Burman Rivers. d.Supporting Conuma Chinook mark-recapture2.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.3.Monitor the environment in the Mowachaht/ Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such Environment & Climate Change Canada, DFO, Province of BC Forest, Lands and Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, etc. (e.g., derelict float homes, logging erosion, rate of cut considerations affecting salmon production).4. Assist Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) with activities in relation to production Chinook from the Gold and Burman Rivers satellite programs with Conuma hatchery (e.g., Chinook, chum and brood-stock collections, biosampling provide NSWS assistance for feeding net pen Chinook, assist Conuma hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon) and participate in the annual production planning for Conuma hatchery with DFO SEP staff 5.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Conuma Chinook, Coho and Chum. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries program staff and the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with Conuma DFO enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager in August.6.Participate in juvenile fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys according to survey schedules as follows:a.Oktwanch and Burman rivers Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment Biologist (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Reports summarizing CREEL results including effort, catch and gear type, provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.3.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to.4.Summary of number of employees assisting Conuma hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of Mowachaht/Muchalaht priorities and  recommendations regarding Conuma hatchery production planning and other salmon enhancement efforts for Area 25 will be provided to DFO SEP through production planning process.6.Signed ESSR Agreement (if viable ESSR opportunity develops) and completion of all catch reporting requirements  provided to DFO Resource Manager (Amy Greenwood) weekly. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.7.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column3: 1.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor, sound, and survey herring spawning waters.2.Nuchatlaht Fisheries staff will monitor and survey spawning streams for salmon.  Reporting live count and carcasses on 2 streams: Espinosa, Savey Creek (Owossista, and Mary Basin, if conditions permit). 3.Nuchatlaht staff will monitor spawning waters for both herring and salmon for activities that may impact spawning areas, such as upland activity disturbances that may affect water, sediment and large wood debris, cover in the "shore zone," and/or sedimentation of salmon spawning habitat.4.Nuchatlaht staff will plan protections for estuaries and watersheds from industrial activities in the form of Salmon Forest Conservation Areas in the Owiissta/Apple Creeks and the Shoomaht/Ransom Creek (Nuu-chah-nulth Salmon Forest Ecological Network watersheds).

Reporting live count and carcasses on 2 streams: Espinosa, Savey Creek (Owossista, and Mary Basin, if conditions permit). 3.Nuchatlaht staff will monitor spawning waters for both herring and salmon for activities that may impact spawning areas, such as upland activity disturbances that may affect water, sediment and large wood debris, cover in the "shore zone," and/or sedimentation of salmon spawning habitat.4.Nuchatlaht staff will plan protections for estuaries and watersheds from industrial activities in the form of Salmon Forest Conservation Areas in the Owiissta/Apple Creeks and the Shoomaht/Ransom Creek (Nuu-chah-nulth Salmon Forest Ecological Network watersheds).
column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Nuchatlaht
column11: 1.Salmon escapement survey work by the Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries staff includes:a.Conducting escapement surveys for sockeye salmon on the Oktwanch River (Gold) from September to early November.b.Conducting a bus route survey for Oktwanch River (Gold River) sockeye fisheries c. Supporting contracted escapement projects with DFO StAD tentatively identified at Tsowwin, Canton, and Oktwanch and Burman Rivers. d.Supporting Conuma Chinook mark-recapture2.Marine bio-toxins are monitored weekly from May to October for CFIA.3.Monitor the environment in the Mowachaht/ Muchalaht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such Environment & Climate Change Canada, DFO, Province of BC Forest, Lands and Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, etc. (e.g., derelict float homes, logging erosion, rate of cut considerations affecting salmon production).4. Assist Nootka Sound Watershed Society (NSWS) with activities in relation to production Chinook from the Gold and Burman Rivers satellite programs with Conuma hatchery (e.g., Chinook, chum and brood-stock collections, biosampling provide NSWS assistance for feeding net pen Chinook, assist Conuma hatchery staff in release of juvenile salmon) and participate in the annual production planning for Conuma hatchery with DFO SEP staff 5.Development of an ESSR Agreement for Conuma Chinook, Coho and Chum. Mowachaht/Muchalaht Fisheries program staff and the Organization's Northern Region Fisheries Biologist will work with Conuma DFO enhancement Facility Manager and DFO WCVI AFS Manager in August.6.Participate in juvenile fall salmon stock assessment survey planning with DFO Stock Assessment Biologist.
column12: 1.Results of escapement surveys according to survey schedules as follows:a.Oktwanch and Burman rivers Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey results will be reported to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment Biologist (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) on Stream Inspection Logs in-season.  The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.b.Reports summarizing CREEL results including effort, catch and gear type, provided to DFO South Coast Stock Assessment (cc DFO WCVI AFS Manager) in-season. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.2.Samples are sent to CFIA weekly from May to October via pre-paid courier. Provide date and method of submission to CFIA in the AFS Year End Report.3.Summary of monitoring concerns and resulting referrals will be included in the AFS Year End Report including which agency and contact the concerns were delivered to.4.Summary of number of employees assisting Conuma hatchery and list of activities they were involved with, to be included in the AFS Year End Report.5.Summary of Mowachaht/Muchalaht priorities and  recommendations regarding Conuma hatchery production planning and other salmon enhancement efforts for Area 25 will be provided to DFO SEP through production planning process.6.Signed ESSR Agreement (if viable ESSR opportunity develops) and completion of all catch reporting requirements  provided to DFO Resource Manager (Amy Greenwood) weekly. Provide date and method of submission to DFO in the AFS Year End Report.7.Salmon Escapement Enumeration Survey planning results and decisions will be provided in the AFS Year End Report.

column5: Stock Assessment and Fisheries Management- Tla-o-qui-aht
column11: 1.Conduct broodstock capture in the Upper Kennedy River. Training of hatchery staff, dealing with the fertilization, incubation and rearing of chinook eggs and fry.2.Plan to expand Tla-o-qui-aht's hatchery operations by investigating the feasibility of other enhancement sites and enhancement of other species (i.e. Sockeye). This will be done in conjunction with Kennedy Watershed Sockeye restoration planning.3.Conduct and/or assist with escapement surveys according to survey schedule developed with DFO and Tla-o-qui-aht Fisheries staff on Kennedy River systems (i.e. Muriel Lake, Staghorn Creek, Angora Creek and Lower Kennedy and Kennedy Lake).4.Conduct three or more general monitoring surveys (e.g. sea otters) and other surveys as contracted by DFO (if applicable). Monitor the environment in Tla-o-qui-aht Ha-houlthee and report concerns to community and appropriate agency staff such as Ministry of Environment and DFO.  When a specific DFO survey contract is awarded, the report on surveys will distinguish AFS funded activities versus non-AFS funded activities.
column12: 1.Summary of broodstock capture dates and activities supporting SEP activities in the Kennedy watershed will be included in the AFS Year End Report2. The actual dates and method of reporting to DFO will be included in the AFS Year End Report.4.Summary of results will be included in the AFS Year End Report. 5.Summary of survey and monitoring results to relevant DFO staff (cc WCVI AFS Manager), and dates and results of survey listed in AFS Year End Report. (e.g., sea otter survey information will be reported to DFO Science Branch, in-season and summarized in the AFS Year End Report).

column12: 1.A copy of the DFO / Ha’wiih/ Chief and Council approved F&C fishing plan and summary of the season’s results will be provided to DFO (WCVI AFS Manager) and the Organization’s Central Region Fisheries Biologist.  Date and method of submission to DFO will be provided in the AFS Year End Report. 2.Catch monitoring results, scheduled reporting of F&C landings and released fish provided to DFO WCVI AFS Manager and the Organization's Central Region Fisheries Biologist using the Catch Reporting Template provided by NTC as follows:a.Fraser Sockeye -Weekly on the Wednesday of each week, during the fishing season.b.All ocean salmon will be recorded by month and reported on September 30, December 1 and April 8, 2022. f.Harvests by a commercial fishing vessel on a dual fishing trip or a contracted fishing trip will be reported within 24 hours after landing.g.In season management - provide DFO updated catch reporting when there is a need to assess supplemental harvest requests.

column3: In July and August, the Fisheries Project Supervisor (FPS) and up to four Salmon Assessment Technicians will participate in pink and chum creek walks for the following systems in the Bella Coola Valley: Thorsen, Noohalk, Garbage, Tatsquan, Fish, Klonnic, George Hall, Airport, Saloompt, Snootli, Necleetsconnay, Clayton, Noosgulch. Nuxalk Creek walkers will work with DFO Snootli Creek Hatchery staff or DFO StAD Biologist on DFO Stream Inspection Log (SIL) forms to learn about the up-dated standards for form completion.
column11: Area and species specific catch data are received weekly by DFO Fisheries Resource Manager, Bill Waugh, by Wednesday of each week for incorporation into the management of salmon in the Taku River drainage and to ensure community needs are met.
column12: The Organization will provide a post season summary and details of the Catch Reporting Project in their Year End Report.

column3: In July and August, the Fisheries Project Supervisor (FPS) and up to four Salmon Assessment Technicians will participate in pink and chum creek walks for the following systems in the Bella Coola Valley: Thorsen, Noohalk, Garbage, Tatsquan, Fish, Klonnic, George Hall, Airport, Saloompt, Snootli, Necleetsconnay, Clayton, Noosgulch. Nuxalk Creek walkers will work with DFO Snootli Creek Hatchery staff or DFO StAD Biologist on DFO Stream Inspection Log (SIL) forms to learn about the up-dated standards for form completion.
column11: 1.FSC catch numbers will be used as important input for the terminal chinook commercial fishery openings operating within DFO Management Area 8.  2.The conservation of salmon can be better maintained through sound joint management decisions (by the Organization and DFO) based on accurate data collected in a timely manner.3.The catch calendars will assist the River Monitors in collecting catch data that may have been missed, thus increasing the accuracy of catches, and catches of species other than salmon. They will also help to improve community awareness and support for FSC catch monitoring.
column12: 1.FSC salmon catch data (including the salmon totals and total fishing effort) will be coded and provided to a DFO Central Coast Resource Manager on a daily basis for chinook and monthly for sockeye, pink and chum. Due to run timing, if additional funding is available, coho catch numbers will be provided as well. 2.A preliminary summary of the available Nuxalk Bella Coola River FSC salmon catch data will be provided to DFO Central Coast Resource Manager, by October 31 each year. 3.Finalized Nuxalk Bella Coola River FSC salmon catch data will be provided to DFO Central Coast Resource Manager, by January 31 each year. 4.Any catch data on other species (i.e. groundfish, shellfish and herring) will be summarized and included in the Year End Report.

column3: In July and August, the Fisheries Project Supervisor (FPS) and up to four Salmon Assessment Technicians will participate in pink and chum creek walks for the following systems in the Bella Coola Valley: Thorsen, Noohalk, Garbage, Tatsquan, Fish, Klonnic, George Hall, Airport, Saloompt, Snootli, Necleetsconnay, Clayton, Noosgulch. Nuxalk Creek walkers will work with DFO Snootli Creek Hatchery staff or DFO StAD Biologist on DFO Stream Inspection Log (SIL) forms to learn about the up-dated standards for form completion.
column11: 1. Spawning escapement will be observed and recorded on DFO SIL forms (following up-dated standards) for the tributaries close to the community. 2. The health of the pink and chum salmon runs will be monitored and reported.
column12: Complete SIL forms will be forwarded to DFO Central Coast Resouce Management within 24 hours of each walk.

column11: 1. Spawning escapement will be observed and recorded on DFO SIL forms (following up-dated standards) for the tributaries close to the community. 2. The health of the pink and chum salmon runs will be monitored and reported.
column12: Complete SIL forms will be forwarded to DFO Central Coast Resouce Management within 24 hours of each walk.

column3: Bio-Samplers will work in conjunction with Nuxalk River Monitors to collect biological samples and provide additional catch monitoring support in the Nuxalk FSC Fishery. This sampling program is designed to: 1.Collect the age and catch information for Atnarko Chinook that is necessary to monitor the wild stock's status over time. 2.Collect samples on Atnarko Sockeye that can be analyzed for changes in growth, age, and genetics over time (before and after the sockeye crash). This has been identified as a very high priority for Atnarko Sockeye in the 2016 Atnarko Sockeye Recovery Plan (Nuxalk Nation, CCIRA) and again at the Atnarko Sockeye Recovery Plan Update meeting in 2019. 3.Additional outcomes are also possible by continuing to collect these samples, such as indexing the proportion of non-Atnarko Chinook present in the FSC catch to estimate total returns to the Bella Coola.  For Chinook: the Bio-Samplers will collect fishing information, the length, mark status, sex, scales, and the snout of AD clipped Chinook. A goal is to sample 20% of the daily non-adipose clipped reported catch to ensure samples are representative of run timing and run size over the fishing season. Samplers will work to sample and collect heads from as many hatchery adipose-clipped fish as possible. Each adipose-clipped fish snout will be collected and tagged with a specific FSC label provided by DFO each year using swift attacher gun. This number will be carefully recorded on each bio-sampling sheet. At the end of each day, chinook snouts will be placed separately without touching each other into a deep freezer. For Sockeye: the Bio-Samplers will collect fishing information, the length, mark status, sex, and 5 scales from as many sockeye as possible. All biological data will be recorded in the datasheet format created by DFO with Nuxalk Stewardship Office before the program starts. Scale books must be filled out completely using pencil by samplers and be kept in a dry place. Staff will be trained how to correctly mount the scales rough-side up. CWT heads will be inventoried and packaged weekly to ensure datasheets and head label numbers are recorded correctly on datasheets. Once each box is packaged, shipment and storage of FSC heads will be coordinated with Bella Coola DFO Stock Assessment.  Items to be provided by DFO to Nuxalk Stewardship office: Electronic copies of jointly finalized data sheets and databases; FSC head labels; Swift attach guns; Sockeye and Chinook scale sampling books; Temporary green labels for monitors; and Any training documents or materials requested by Nuxalk Stewardship Office for staff training.

column11: 1. Nuxalk Stewardship staff to collect and store data and samples from Bella Coola caught salmon from the FSC fishery in 2020 according to agreed upon instructions. 2. Samplers and monitors to be trained in the importance of their work and they will communicate the importance of annual programs for Atnarko Sockeye recovery to the best of their abilities when interacting with fishers and fish processors. 3. All adipose clipped chinook heads will be frozen as instructions provided. Then inventoried and shipped out for dissection by coordinating with Bella Coola DFO Stock Assessment.
column12: 1. All full, partial and emty scale books will be provided from the 2020 season by the end of August separated by species. 2. A complete database with all datasheets transcribed in Excel for sockeye biological sampling, and river-monitoring sheets by October 5th. 3. Hardcopies of all original datasheets from the biological sampling and catch monitoring in order of date for DFO stock assessement to use for troubleshooting any database issues.

column3: 1.Two River Monitors will actively monitor the salmon Food Fishery together in the Bella Coola Valley from May to September. They will observe and record salmon catches by species and by drift and/or set net. At times, the monitors will be stationed on certain areas of the river, and other times they will be travelling to fishing locations for spot checks. 2.The Central Coast FSC catch database will again be used along with FSC catch calendars (if funding allows).  Catch calendars will be issued by the Fisheries Project Supervisor (or the Stewardship Administrator) to the fishers and the FSC data entered into the database.  3.The River Monitors will submit weekly written reports to the Fisheries Project Supervisor. Monthly reports will be provided to Nuxalk Stewardship Director.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: Area and species specific catch data are received weekly by DFO Fisheries Resource Manager, Bill Waugh, by Wednesday of each week for incorporation into the management of salmon in the Taku River drainage and to ensure community needs are met.
column12: The Organization will provide a post season summary and details of the Catch Reporting Project in their Year End Report.

column3: 1. The Organization will install and operate adult/carcass enumeration fences at three remote locations in the Taku River Drainage for the purposes of enumerating adult salmon returns, ensuring passage and assessing the biological stock characteristics.
column11: 1. Employment of up to 8 Members for approximately 10 person months; develop technical capacity in stock assessment techniques. 2.Cumulative counts, tag recovery/loss information and number of samples obtained to date will be reported to the Fisheries Coordinator on a weekly basis, on Wednesday of each week, and this information will in turn be provided to DFO Senior Stock Assessment Biologist, Aaron Foos.
column12: 1. The PM will provide samples and associated data to DFO Senior Stock Assessment Biologist, Aaron Foos, by September 30. 2. Summary reports on the individual tasks are included in the Year End Report.

column3: A Taku River Tlingit Elder will work alongside staff to provide advice and culturally appropriate approaches to management issues.

1. The organization will monitor the FSC Fishery at 3 remote locations and collect food Fish data by species and amount by week. At Cranberry Island, catches are tallied by staff at the existing landing station for the commercial fishery operation by Taku River Tlingit and Taku Wild. At Kathai and King Salmon, staff monitoring the weirs are able to monitor fishing activity, which takes place under their supervision at the weir sites.

column3: Funding to purchase the materials and design a building for storage/maintenance of equipment for ongoing fisheries management projects.
column5: Operational Infrastructure Capacity Fund - Materials and Building Design

column3: Conduct work to expand and deepen the rock notch at in the Silver Salmon River (site SR3) to increase flow to the river and left side of the obstacle, impacting on salmon migration in the river to Kuthai Lake.
column5: Silver Salmon River Fish Passage Improvements
column11: The TRT staff to complete assessment of work site obstruction impacting on migration of salmon up the Silver Salmon River.  Set up safety rope systems and minor instream diversions to ensure a dry work area (where required) and exclude any fish. Rock work will be conducted by a combination of hammer drill and rock saw to deepen the river left notch/kerf cuts inside the existing rock work area, to bring a more even split of flow between the river right side of the obstruction and the river left side. This is intended to provide better depth and improved low flow passage through the passage enhancement works. Once completed assessment of site will include jump attempt monitoring and digital video recording of jump attempts, as well as beaver dam management within the river.
column12: All of the field activities will be captured in a summary report. Products/Reports to provide to DFO.

column3: Annual training and recertification needs vary with returning and/or new staff.

(Existing activity under AFS) Lengthening the duration of and providing additional support for the mark-recpature program (FYI, funding received from other sources as well: Province's Environmental Stewardship Initiative and for steelhead tagging). Sockeye and coho selected for tagging will be tagged with TBA-1, Hallprint tags and collect biological samples including scale in Upper Bulkley River, Morice Lake, and Atna Lake.
column11: 1.Maintain boats and vehicle for the tagging program. 2. Installation of bridges to Fishing sites, safety ropes, maintenance of project related Fishing gear. 3.Conduct pre-season test Fishing to determine when sampling activity should begin. 4. Hire labourers to transport equipment and gear for tagging operations, and to maintain and repair truck, insure truck, inspect truck for compliance with Department of Highways regulations. 5. Update the daily tagging data form developed in 2014 as necessary. This form is used to make in season estimates. 6.The FM will help ensure data is gathered and stored in a manner that safeguards the data, and ensures the data is accurate. 7.Conduct aerial spawner counts for Chinook, Coho, Sockeye and Pink in conjunction with DFO. 8.Conduct dead pitches in the Nanika River to supplement the Mark/Recapture program and swim Nanika River to count Sockeye spawners, noting tagged to untagged rations.  DFO will generate population estimates. 9. Conduct stream walks in the Morice River 1km from Morice Lake at the Dunes for Chinook enumeration. 10.Conduct stream walks in the Morice River Mainstem to count Sockeye and Sockeye spawners.11.Provide DFO Stock Assessment and Skeena Fisheries Commission Staff with Coho estimate data. This will be used in conjunction with the Tyee Test DNA to produce a total Skeena Coho population estimate. 12.Maintain employment for existing technical staff for the extended duration of the program. 13.Continued expansion of technical capacity for the Wet'suwet'en Treaty Office Society Fisheries Program.

column3: Wet'suwet'en Fisheries Staff will conduct habitat protection and monitoring activities to assist in habitat baseline information collection, habitat protection and conservation efforts within the Wet'suwet'en asserted area. 2. The Organization will monitor the functionality of various in-stream structures including culverts and forest service roads within the Morice Watershed. The Organization will review proposals and attend any meetings related to proposed linear development or resource extraction development within the Wet'suwet'en asserted area.
column11: 1.Water quality, flow and temperature monitoring in Moricetown Canyon. 2.Continue the existing water quality monitoring program for the special water management area in the upper Morice watershed that was created through the Morice LRMP. 3.Review plans and attend meetings for any mines, pipelines or other industrial developments that may have an impact on habitat within the Wet'suwet'en asserted area. 4.Country food (food Fish) will be monitored for contaminants. 5.Habitat and Fish inventory at pipeline crossing sites. 6.Establish baseline data for country foods (food Fish) down streams of potential crossing locations.
column12: 1.Information collected and concerns from the Wet'suwet'en Fisheries Staff specific to a land or water development proposal will be provided to the Office of the Wet'suwet'en, DFO, and Provincial Governments and to various industry representatives as applicable. 2.A summary of Habitat Monitoring and Restoration activities will be provided to DFO in the Year End Report. 3. Any habitat violation concerns will be reported immediately to Smithers DFO C&P Officers.

column3: The Organization will purchase a pickup truck to replace the aging vehicle that is in need of extensive repairs.

Catch Monitoring of all species will continue in Moricetown Canyon.  Data will be used to calculate inseason catch estimates of the Wet'suwet'en Fisheries and be reported weekly to DFO in Prince Rupert and Smithers.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: 1.Up to 8 seasonal catch monitor positions will be created. 2.Species and catch numbers released and observed will be recorded at 2 hour intervals from dawn to dusk at FSC Fishing sites. 3.Monitoring data will be entered into a Microsoft Access database.
column12: 1.In-season FSC catch numbers will be submitted to DFO Implementation Officer, Andrea Komlos, on a weekly basis. 2.A summary of FSC harvest will be provided by October 31 of that year and within the Year End Report and submitted to DFO in Smithers.

column3: Replace existing motor.
column5: Purchase Mercury 200 Optimax Powerhead Boat Motor and jet pump package

column3: Build a tagging boat suitable for Bulkley River and AFG activities.
column5: Operational Capacity Funding- Capital Acquisition; Boat hull replacement

column3: Wet'suwet'en Fisheries Staff will continue with the Mark/Recapture Project that provides a population estimate of salmon destined for spawning grounds above the Moricetown Canyon in season, as well as to tag Steelhead for other studies that may occur during the fall and spring.  In addition to tagging the salmonids, data such as sex, length and condition is compiled.  Special emphasis will be given to observe/record the damage conditions of salmon this year with consequent monitoring on the spawning beds. Research suggests that high infection rates with a fungus (Saprolegnia spp.) entering the fish body through net marks and other skin damage causes significant mortalities.   The Mark/Recapture program is mainly funded through stock assessment and the top up of funds is supported through the AFS program.
column11: 1.Maintain boats and vehicle for the tagging program. 2. Update the daily tagging data form developed in 2014 as necessary. This form is used to make in season estimates. 6.The FM will help ensure data is gathered and stored in a manner that safeguards the data, and ensures the data is accurate. 7.Conduct aerial spawner counts for Chinook, Coho, Sockeye and Pink in conjunction with DFO. 8.Conduct dead pitches in the Nanika River to supplement the Mark/Recapture program and swim Nanika River to count Sockeye spawners, noting tagged to untagged rations.  DFO will generate population estimates. 9. This will be used in conjunction with the Tyee Test DNA to produce a total Skeena Coho population estimate. 12.Maintain employment for existing technical staff for the extended duration of the program. 13.Continued expansion of technical capacity for the Wet'suwet'en Treaty Office Society Fisheries Program.

Research suggests that high infection rates with a fungus (Saprolegnia spp.) entering the fish body through net marks and other skin damage causes significant mortalities.   The Mark/Recapture program is mainly funded through stock assessment and the top up of funds is supported through the AFS program.
column11: 1.Maintain boats and vehicle for the tagging program. 2. Installation of bridges to Fishing sites, safety ropes, maintenance of project related Fishing gear. 3.Conduct pre-season test Fishing to determine when sampling activity should begin. 4. Hire labourers to transport equipment and gear for tagging operations, and to maintain and repair truck, insure truck, inspect truck for compliance with Department of Highways regulations. 5. Update the daily tagging data form developed in 2014 as necessary. This form is used to make in season estimates. 6.The FM will help ensure data is gathered and stored in a manner that safeguards the data, and ensures the data is accurate. 7.Conduct aerial spawner counts for Chinook, Coho, Sockeye and Pink in conjunction with DFO. 8.Conduct dead pitches in the Nanika River to supplement the Mark/Recapture program and swim Nanika River to count Sockeye spawners, noting tagged to untagged rations.  DFO will generate population estimates. 9. Conduct stream walks in the Morice River 1km from Morice Lake at the Dunes for Chinook enumeration. 10.Conduct stream walks in the Morice River Mainstem to count Sockeye and Sockeye spawners.11.Provide DFO Stock Assessment and Skeena Fisheries Commission Staff with Coho estimate data. This will be used in conjunction with the Tyee Test DNA to produce a total Skeena Coho population estimate. 12.Maintain employment for existing technical staff for the extended duration of the program. 13.Continued expansion of technical capacity for the Wet'suwet'en Treaty Office Society Fisheries Program.

column3: 1.Fisheries technicians will monitor the dates and approximate number of spawning salmon. 2. Approximately 22 survey days (7 hour days) are planned for crews to assess the run on all creeks identified.  Surveys will be conducted between August and late November, 2021.
column11: Support forecasting sockeye returns. Provides insight into lake productivity. Complements the Stamp and Sproat enumeration programs to generate escapement estimates as part of Hupacasath’s AFS agreement.
column12: Smolt out-flow data. Biological data as requested (length & scale samples).

column11: 1.Complete Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) for all surveys conducted.2.Work with DFO Stock Assessment to produce annual estimates for all streams surveyed.
column12: 1.SILs delivered by November 24, 2021 or one week after the last survey. 2.Annual estimates to be produced with DFO consultation after SILs received and processed.

column3: 1.The Organization's catch monitoring and record keeping for harvests under the Food,Social and Ceremonial Fisheries will be conducted by two Aboriginal Monitors with assistance from the Fisheries Coordinator.2.The Aboriginal Monitors will conduct separate checks along the Skeena River starting mid-May to mid-September; interviews will be done with First Nations participating in the harvest of salmon resources for FSC purposes.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: 1.Complete Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) for all surveys conducted.2.Work with DFO Stock Assessment to produce annual estimates for all streams surveyed.
column12: 1.SILs delivered by November 24, 2021 or one week after the last survey. 2.Annual estimates to be produced with DFO consultation after SILs received and processed.

column3: 1.The Organization will work collaboratively with BC Parks and DFO on the stewardship of the Goldstream Watershed by maintaining regular communications and attending related planning meetings. 2.The Organization's staff will pursue opportunities to be trained in stock assessment techniques, which may include but is not limited to, joining stream walks and/or arranging meetings with DFO StAD to discuss stock assessment techniques).
column11: 1.Complete Stream Inspection Logs (SILs) for all surveys conducted.2.Work with DFO Stock Assessment to produce annual estimates for all streams surveyed.
column12: 1.SILs delivered by November 24, 2021 or one week after the last survey. 2.Annual estimates to be produced with DFO consultation after SILs received and processed.

column3: 1.The FC/FT will coordinate catch monitoring and reporting as agreed to in the AFS Agreement. 2.The FC/FT, in consultation with DFO, will develop a detailed operational plan that outlines the proposed fishing activities for the year and the specific fisheries management activities to be undertaken by the Organization.3.The FC/FT will collect all known weekly catch information for all fish including shellfish harvested by the Organization or designate, in a suitable format to the DFO Area Species Coordinators as identified by Jonathan Joe, DFO Resource Manager.4.The FC will employ individual(s) as it deems necessary to undertake catch monitoring and reportings. 5.The FC/FT will maintain records of catch throughout the year for all species possible and summarize information for a final report.6.The FC/FT will assign and manage fishing permits, including communal licences to designated persons and vessels.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: 1.All data collected by the Aboriginal Monitors will be submitted monthly to DFO NC Aboriginal programs staff and also provided on the weekly in-season calls. 2.Any incidents will be documented and reported to the Kitsumkalum Aboriginal Fishery Guardian.  The Aboriginal Fishery Guardian will fill in the proper required documentation and submit it to the DFO C&P staff in Terrace.
column12: 1.A summary Catch Monitoring Report will be submitted with the Year End Report.

column3: The Organization will sample Chinook and Sockeye salmon harvested in the Upper Stikine River FSC fishery, implement adult Chinook salmon assessment projects, and conduct aerial surveys for Stikine River sockeye and Coho salmon
column11: 1.Employment of 4 community members for approximately 9 months; develop technical capacity in stock assessment techniques. 2. Achieve target samples, apportioned to run strength and according to protocols included in operational plans. 3.Cumulative counts, tag recovery information, and number of samples obtained to date from the Upper Stikine are reported to the Fisheries Manager on a weekly basis. 4. Index areas for Sockeye and Coho salmon are surveyed by helicopter. 5.Assessment of the Chinook salmon run to the Little Tahltan River using video enumeration methodologies.
column12: 1.The Fisheries Manager shall provide Upper Stikine River samples by mail and associated data in excel via email to DFO Stock Assessment Project Coordinator Johnny.Sembsmoen@dfo-mpo.gc.ca by September 1, 2021. 2.Tallies of aerial counts by index areas (shared survey with DFO - results are tallied and included in Transboundary Technical Committee annual reports). 3.Copies of the daily Little Tahltan River Chinook salmon count files to Stock Assessment Project Coordinator Johnny.Sembsmoen@dfo-mpo.gc.ca by September 1, 2021 for verification and inclusion in the Transboundary Technical Committee annual reports. 4.Summary Reports on the individual projects are included in the Year End Report.

column12: 1.The Fisheries Manager shall provide Upper Stikine River samples by mail and associated data in excel via email to DFO Stock Assessment Project Coordinator Johnny.Sembsmoen@dfo-mpo.gc.ca by September 1, 2021. 2.Tallies of aerial counts by index areas (shared survey with DFO - results are tallied and included in Transboundary Technical Committee annual reports). 3.Copies of the daily Little Tahltan River Chinook salmon count files to Stock Assessment Project Coordinator Johnny.Sembsmoen@dfo-mpo.gc.ca by September 1, 2021 for verification and inclusion in the Transboundary Technical Committee annual reports. 4.Summary Reports on the individual projects are included in the Year End Report.

column3: 1.Through the TCG, a Fisheries Technical Officer will issue fishing permits and collect food fish data in the Stikine River watershed from approximately May 20 through August 30, 2021. The Fisheries Technical Officer shall monitor the food fishery based at Tahltan and will ensure that fish leaving the Telegraph Creek area are accompanied by valid Tahltan Fisheries transportation permits and will work with DFO/RCMP enforcement personnel where required. The Fisheries Technical Officer shall conduct a creel survey of the Organization area recreational fishery as outlined in operational plans to determine catch and effort data for Chinook salmon. 2.The Fisheries Manager shall also issue food fish permits, where required, from the Tahltan Band Council office or other designated locations.
column4: Food, Social and Ceremonial (FSC) Fisheries Management
column11: 1.Employment of one community member for approximately 14 weeks. 2.Weekly food fish reports, summarized by species, are received by the Fisheries Manager and in turn provided to Bill.Waugh@dfo-mpo.gc.ca at DFO Whitehorse. 3.Improved catch reporting, education of Tahltan fishers and visitors, better local control of FSC fishing activity, and monitoring of fish transport outside of Tahltan asserted traditional territory. 4.Estimates of recreational fishing activity and harvest (Chinook) are reported in the post-season.
column12: 1.Weekly reports as outlined in operational plans. The TCG will include details of the Catch Monitoring and FSC catch reporting project in their Year End Report. 2.Creel data is sent to DFO by September 30, 2021.  The TCG will include details of the creel census and biological sampling in the Year End Report.
